introduction.title: How Cloud Computing Works

@introduction.title.description: Main heading for the introduction screen of the interactive cloud computing tutorial

introduction.description: This short, interactive activity will guide you through the methods and techniques of the cloud, from its foundations to its deployment.

@introduction.description.description: Brief description of what the user will learn in this activity

introduction.part1.title: Part 1: Foundations.

@introduction.part1.title.description: Title for the first learning section about cloud computing basics

introduction.part1.description: Tackle 'Myth vs. Fact' questions about what the cloud really is.

@introduction.part1.description.description: Description of the first activity - a quiz format about cloud fundamentals

introduction.part2.title: Part 2: Service Models.

@introduction.part2.title.description: Title for the second learning section about cloud service types

introduction.part2.description: Play a drag-and-drop game to sort IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS.

@introduction.part2.description.description: Description of the second activity - interactive sorting game. IaaS, PaaS, and SaaS are technical acronyms that should not be translated

introduction.part3.title: Part 3: Deployment Models.

@introduction.part3.title.description: Title for the third learning section about cloud deployment types

introduction.part3.description: Solve real-world scenarios to understand Public, Private, and Hybrid clouds.

@introduction.part3.description.description: Description of the third activity - scenario-based learning about deployment types

@introduction.button.start.description: Call-to-action button to begin the learning activity

part1.title: Part 1: The Foundation

@part1.title.description: Header for the foundation quiz section

part1.subtitle: Is the following statement a myth or a fact?

@part1.subtitle.description: Instruction text explaining the quiz format to users

@part1.button.fact.description: Button label for selecting that a statement is true/factual

@part1.button.myth.description: Button label for selecting that a statement is false/myth

part1.feedback.correct.title: Correct!

@part1.feedback.correct.title.description: Positive feedback shown when user selects the right answer

part1.feedback.incorrect.title: Not Quite!

@part1.feedback.incorrect.title.description: Gentle feedback shown when user selects the wrong answer

@part1.button.next.description: Button to proceed to the next quiz question

@part1.button.continue.description: Button to proceed to next section after completing all questions

part1.question1.statement: The foundations of cloud computing are high-powered computers called servers, located in facilities called data centers.

@part1.question1.statement.description: Quiz statement about the physical infrastructure of cloud computing

part1.question1.explanation: That's right! The cloud's central innovation is placing large numbers of servers in data centers, typically located far from the individuals and organizations that access them.

@part1.question1.explanation.description: Educational explanation shown after answering the question correctly or incorrectly

part1.question2.statement: Cloud computing requires organizations to buy and operate their own computer equipment on-premises.

@part1.question2.statement.description: Quiz statement about cloud vs on-premises computing

part1.question2.explanation: Exactly. Historically, organizations operated their own on-premises equipment. Cloud computing allows them to access resources remotely from a cloud provider instead.

@part1.question2.explanation.description: Educational explanation about the evolution from on-premises to cloud computing

part2.title: Part 2: Service Models

@part2.title.description: Header for the service models sorting game section

part2.subtitle: Drag each example to the correct service model category.
part2.examples.title: Examples

@part2.examples.title.description: Label for the list of examples that users will drag and drop

part2.feedback.correct.title: Correct!

@part2.feedback.correct.title.description: Positive feedback when user places example in correct category

part2.feedback.incorrect.title: Not Quite...

@part2.feedback.incorrect.title.description: Gentle feedback when user places example in wrong category

@part2.feedback.button.gotit.description: Button to dismiss feedback modal and try again

@part2.allsorted.message.description: Success message shown when all examples are correctly categorized

@part2.button.continue.description: Button to proceed to next section after completing sorting

part2.example1.text: Paying for storage space that automatically scales to match the amount of data in use.

@part2.example1.text.description: Example of cloud storage service for categorization exercise

part2.example1.correct: You got it. Scalable storage is a core component of infrastructure that you rent from a provider. This is a classic IaaS offering.

@part2.example1.correct.description: Explanation when correctly categorized as IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service)

part2.example1.hint.paas: While a PaaS application would *use* storage, the storage service itself is a more fundamental building block. It's part of the core infrastructure.

@part2.example1.hint.paas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as PaaS instead of IaaS

part2.example1.hint.saas: This isn't a complete application, but a raw component you'd use to build one. Which model provides these fundamental building blocks?

@part2.example1.hint.saas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as SaaS instead of IaaS

part2.example2.text: Using Zoom for video calls or Slack for messaging.

@part2.example2.text.description: Example of ready-to-use software applications. Zoom and Slack are product names that should not be translated

part2.example2.correct: That's it! These are examples of complete software products that you access, typically by paying a subscription. This is Software as a Service.

@part2.example2.correct.description: Explanation when correctly categorized as SaaS (Software as a Service)

part2.example2.hint.iaas: With Zoom or Slack, are you managing servers or just using an app? IaaS is about renting the servers themselves. This is a level above that.

@part2.example2.hint.iaas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as IaaS instead of SaaS. Zoom and Slack should not be translated

part2.example2.hint.paas: PaaS is a platform for developers to *create* apps. Zoom is an app that has already been created for you to use. Which model fits that description?

@part2.example2.hint.paas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as PaaS instead of SaaS. Zoom should not be translated

part2.example3.text: Operating your own software in the cloud while a provider handles and maintains the servers.

@part2.example3.text.description: Example of platform service for running custom applications

part2.example3.correct: Perfect! With PaaS, you focus on your application code, while the provider handles the underlying infrastructure and technical responsibilities, like server maintenance.

@part2.example3.correct.description: Explanation when correctly categorized as PaaS (Platform as a Service)

part2.example3.hint.iaas: You're getting warmer! IaaS would give you the server, but you would be responsible for maintaining it. This service handles that maintenance for you.

@part2.example3.hint.iaas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as IaaS instead of PaaS

part2.example3.hint.saas: This is a model for *running* your own software, not for *using* someone else's. Which category provides that kind of platform?

@part2.example3.hint.saas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as SaaS instead of PaaS

part2.example4.text: Accessing a file sharing service to collaborate with a team.

@part2.example4.text.description: Example of collaboration software for teams

part2.example4.correct: Correct! A file sharing service is a ready-to-use application provided for end-users, which is the definition of SaaS.

@part2.example4.correct.description: Explanation when correctly categorized as SaaS

part2.example4.hint.iaas: File sharing is a feature of a complete software product. IaaS would be renting the raw storage where those files are kept.

@part2.example4.hint.iaas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as IaaS instead of SaaS

part2.example4.hint.paas: You are *using* a finished service, not *building* one. PaaS is the environment for building. What's the model for using?

@part2.example4.hint.paas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as PaaS instead of SaaS

part2.example5.text: Using a provider's infrastructure for large-scale data processing and analytics.

@part2.example5.text.description: Example of infrastructure service for data processing

part2.example5.correct: Exactly! You are renting the provider's fundamental computing resources (their infrastructure) to perform complex tasks. This is IaaS.

@part2.example5.correct.description: Explanation when correctly categorized as IaaS

part2.example5.hint.paas: PaaS provides a managed platform, but when you're directly utilizing raw processing power and storage for custom analytics, you're using the underlying infrastructure.

@part2.example5.hint.paas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as PaaS instead of IaaS

part2.example5.hint.saas: This describes using core computing power, not a specific, pre-built software application. Which model is about renting raw resources?

@part2.example5.hint.saas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as SaaS instead of IaaS

part2.example6.text: Hosting your company's custom application and its business analytics tools.

@part2.example6.text.description: Example of platform for hosting custom business applications

part2.example6.correct: That's right. When you deploy and run your own software and tools on a managed environment from a cloud provider, that's Platform as a Service.

@part2.example6.correct.description: Explanation when correctly categorized as PaaS

part2.example6.hint.iaas: You could do this with IaaS, but you'd also have to manage the operating systems and servers. PaaS handles that for you so you can focus on your app.

@part2.example6.hint.iaas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as IaaS instead of PaaS

part2.example6.hint.saas: This is about running your *own* custom application, not subscribing to one made by someone else. Which model provides a platform for your own software?

@part2.example6.hint.saas.description: Hint shown when user incorrectly categorizes as SaaS instead of PaaS

part2.hint.default: That doesn't seem to be the right fit. Think about the level of management provided by the service.

@part2.hint.default.description: Generic fallback hint for any incorrect categorization

@part2.tap.place.description: Instruction shown in category boxes when a card is selected (for touch/mobile users)

part3.title: Part 3: Deployment Models

@part3.title.description: Header for the deployment models scenario section

part3.subtitle: Read the scenario and choose the most appropriate cloud model.
part3.feedback.correct.title: Correct!

@part3.feedback.correct.title.description: Positive feedback for selecting the right deployment model

part3.feedback.incorrect.title: Good Try!

@part3.button.next.description: Button to proceed to next scenario question

@part3.button.finish.description: Button to complete the final section and view results

part3.scenario1.text: A financial firm needs to store proprietary research with greater security, requiring an encrypted VPN connection for its employees to access it.

@part3.scenario1.text.description: Business scenario about secure financial data storage. VPN is a technical acronym (Virtual Private Network)

part3.scenario1.explanation: A Private Cloud is ideal here. It offers the greatest security by imposing more restrictions on access, making it suitable for sensitive information like financial records or proprietary research.

@part3.scenario1.explanation.description: Explanation of why Private Cloud is the correct choice for this security-focused scenario

part3.scenario2.text: A software company wants to deploy its app for nearly any customer to use, with easy access over standard internet connections and lower costs.

@part3.scenario2.text.description: Business scenario about wide public accessibility and cost efficiency

part3.scenario2.explanation: A Public Cloud is the perfect choice. They are called 'public' because nearly any customer can pay to use their servers, making them cheaper and offering easy access.

@part3.scenario2.explanation.description: Explanation of why Public Cloud suits mass accessibility and cost considerations

part3.scenario3.text: A company runs its videoconferencing software on a public cloud but stores its sensitive customer service records in a separate, more secure environment.

@part3.scenario3.text.description: Business scenario about splitting workloads between different cloud types

part3.scenario3.explanation: This is a classic Hybrid Cloud. This model involves splitting data and applications across public and private clouds to combine the benefits of both.

@part3.scenario3.explanation.description: Explanation of Hybrid Cloud's ability to combine public and private infrastructures

part3.explanation.default: That's a good thought, but there's a better fit. Consider the key requirements of the scenario.

@part3.explanation.default.description: Generic feedback for incorrect deployment model selection

summary.title: Great Job!
summary.description: You've completed the introduction to how cloud computing works. Here's a quick recap of what you learned.
summary.recap.foundations.title: Foundations:

@summary.recap.foundations.title.description: Section header for cloud computing basics recap

summary.recap.foundations.text: The cloud is a physical network of servers in data centers, accessed remotely.
summary.recap.servicemodels.title: Service Models:

@summary.recap.servicemodels.title.description: Section header for service models recap

summary.recap.iaas: - IaaS is renting a provider's cloud infrastructure (servers, storage).

@summary.recap.iaas.description: Full recap item for IaaS including bullet marker. IaaS is an acronym for Infrastructure as a Service - translate the words but keep the acronym

summary.recap.paas: - PaaS is a platform to operate your own software on, where the provider handles the servers.

@summary.recap.paas.description: Full recap item for PaaS including bullet marker. PaaS is an acronym for Platform as a Service - translate the words but keep the acronym

summary.recap.saas: - SaaS is paying to access another organization's ready-to-use software.

@summary.recap.saas.description: Full recap item for SaaS including bullet marker. SaaS is an acronym for Software as a Service - translate the words but keep the acronym

summary.recap.deploymentmodels.title: Deployment Models:

@summary.recap.deploymentmodels.title.description: Section header for deployment models recap

summary.recap.public: - Public is shared, cost-effective, and easily accessible.

@summary.recap.public.description: Full recap item for Public cloud including bullet marker

summary.recap.private: - Private is dedicated to a single customer for greater security and control.

@summary.recap.private.description: Full recap item for Private cloud including bullet marker

summary.recap.hybrid: - Hybrid combines public and private clouds for flexibility.

@summary.recap.hybrid.description: Full recap item for Hybrid cloud including bullet marker

summary.recap.perspective.title: Perspective Matters:

@summary.recap.perspective.title.description: Section header for perspective insight recap

summary.recap.perspective.text: The same infrastructure can be different service models depending on your role (Netflix uses PaaS, subscribers use SaaS).

@summary.recap.perspective.text.description: Summary of the perspective insight from Part 4

summary.recap.application.title: Real-World Application:

@summary.recap.application.title.description: Section header for application skills recap

summary.recap.application.text: When designing cloud solutions, consider security needs, cost constraints, and how usage might change over time.

@summary.recap.application.text.description: Summary of practical application skills from Part 5

@summary.score.description: Display of user's total score. totalScore and maxScore are numeric values showing points earned out of total possible

@summary.button.restart.description: Button to restart the activity from the beginning

@servicemodel.iaas.description: Full name of IaaS service model category. This is a technical term - translate the words but keep the acronym IaaS

@servicemodel.paas.description: Full name of PaaS service model category. This is a technical term - translate the words but keep the acronym PaaS

@servicemodel.saas.description: Full name of SaaS service model category. This is a technical term - translate the words but keep the acronym SaaS

@deploymentmodel.public.description: Name of public cloud deployment model

@deploymentmodel.private.description: Name of private cloud deployment model

@deploymentmodel.hybrid.description: Name of hybrid cloud deployment model

part4.title: Part 4: Perspective Matters

@part4.title.description: Header for the Netflix perspective-switching section

part4.subtitle: The same cloud infrastructure can be different service models depending on your role.

@part4.subtitle.description: Educational explanation of perspective in service models

part4.instructions: Click the buttons below to switch between Netflix's perspective and a subscriber's perspective:

@part4.instructions.description: Instructions for the interactive perspective switcher

@part4.button.netflix.description: Button to switch to Netflix company perspective

@part4.button.subscriber.description: Button to switch to subscriber/user perspective

part4.netflix.service: Service Model: Platform as a Service (PaaS)

@part4.netflix.service.description: Service model from Netflix company's perspective - PaaS

@part4.netflix.pays.description: Header for what Netflix company pays for

@part4.netflix.pay1.description: First item Netflix pays for - application hosting

@part4.netflix.pay2.description: Second item Netflix pays for - content storage

@part4.netflix.pay3.description: Third item Netflix pays for - network bandwidth

@part4.netflix.manages.description: Header for what Netflix company manages

@part4.netflix.manage1.description: First item Netflix manages - their own software

@part4.netflix.manage2.description: Second item Netflix manages - content and algorithms

@part4.netflix.manage3.description: Third item Netflix manages - user management

@part4.netflix.provider.description: Header for what cloud provider manages for Netflix

@part4.netflix.provider1.description: First item cloud provider manages - servers

@part4.netflix.provider2.description: Second item cloud provider manages - security

@part4.subscriber.role.description: Label showing subscriber's role as end user

part4.subscriber.service: Service Model: Software as a Service (SaaS)

@part4.subscriber.service.description: Service model from subscriber's perspective - SaaS

@part4.subscriber.pays.description: Header for what subscriber pays for

@part4.subscriber.pay1.description: What subscriber pays for - subscription access

part4.subscriber.get2: No software to install or maintain
part4.subscriber.get3: Works on any device with internet
part4.subscriber.notneed: You Don't Need to Know About:

@part4.subscriber.notneed.description: Header for complexity hidden from subscriber

part4.insight: Key Insight: Netflix uses PaaS to run their business, but provides SaaS to you. The same infrastructure serves different purposes!

@part4.insight.description: Educational insight explaining the dual perspective

part4.insight.label: Key Insight

@part4.insight.label.description: Label for the educational insight callout box

part4.progress.label: Explore both perspectives

@part4.progress.label.description: Instruction to view both Netflix and Subscriber perspectives

@part4.progress.viewed.description: Progress counter showing how many perspectives have been explored. {count} is a number (1 or 2)

part5.title: Part 5: Design Your Cloud Solution

@part5.title.description: Header for the cloud solution designer section

part5.subtitle: Apply what you've learned to solve real business challenges.
part5.scenario.label: Scenario:
part5.scenario1.title: Mobile Gaming Startup
part5.scenario1.text: You're launching a mobile game. You expect 1,000 players at launch, but it could grow to 100,000+ if it goes viral. You need to control costs but scale quickly if needed.

@part5.scenario1.text.description: Business scenario for mobile gaming startup with scaling needs

part5.scenario2.title: Healthcare Records System
part5.scenario2.text: A hospital needs to store patient records with strict security requirements. They have 5,000 patients with steady, predictable usage. Data cannot be shared with other organizations.

@part5.scenario2.text.description: Business scenario for healthcare with security and privacy requirements

part5.scenario3.title: E-commerce Platform
part5.scenario3.text: An online store needs to handle normal traffic most of the year, but expects massive spikes during holiday sales. They want flexibility without paying for unused capacity.

@part5.scenario3.text.description: Business scenario for e-commerce with seasonal traffic variation

@part5.choose.service.description: Step 1 instruction for choosing service model

@part5.choose.deployment.description: Step 2 instruction for choosing deployment model

@part5.adjust.scale.description: Step 3 instruction for adjusting user scale

@part5.users.current.description: Display of current user count from slider. count is a numeric value

part5.cost.title: Estimated Monthly Cost:

@part5.cost.amount.description: Cost display with currency. amount is a numeric value

part5.performance.title: Performance:

@part5.button.evaluate.description: Button to check if solution is appropriate

@part5.button.next.description: Button to move to next business scenario

@part5.button.finish.description: Button to finish Part 5 and see summary

part5.feedback.scenario1.ideal: Perfect! PaaS with Public Cloud is ideal for a startup that needs to scale quickly without managing servers. You can grow from thousands to millions of users while only paying for what you use.

@part5.feedback.scenario1.ideal.description: Ideal solution feedback for gaming startup scenario - PaaS + Public

part5.feedback.scenario1.expensive: This works, but Private Cloud is expensive for a startup. You're paying for dedicated infrastructure even when you have few users. Consider Public Cloud to reduce costs.

@part5.feedback.scenario1.expensive.description: Feedback for gaming startup with unnecessarily expensive choice

part5.feedback.scenario1.complex: This works but might be overkill. Hybrid Cloud adds complexity. For a simple mobile game, Public Cloud alone is usually sufficient and easier to manage.

@part5.feedback.scenario1.complex.description: Feedback for gaming startup with unnecessarily complex choice

part5.feedback.scenario2.ideal: Excellent choice! Private Cloud gives you the security and control required for sensitive healthcare data. The steady, predictable usage makes the fixed costs worthwhile.

@part5.feedback.scenario2.ideal.description: Ideal solution feedback for healthcare scenario - Private

part5.feedback.scenario2.security: This could work, but Public Cloud may not meet strict healthcare security requirements. Patient data often requires Private or Hybrid Cloud for compliance and isolation.

@part5.feedback.scenario2.security.description: Feedback for healthcare with insufficient security consideration

part5.feedback.scenario3.ideal: Great thinking! Hybrid Cloud lets you use Private for baseline traffic and burst to Public during holiday spikes. You avoid paying for peak capacity year-round.

@part5.feedback.scenario3.ideal.description: Ideal solution feedback for e-commerce scenario - Hybrid

part5.feedback.scenario3.waste: This works, but you're paying for peak capacity all year when you only need it seasonally. Hybrid Cloud would let you scale up and down more cost-effectively.

@part5.feedback.scenario3.waste.description: Feedback for e-commerce with wasteful capacity planning

part5.feedback.scenario3.public: Good choice! Public Cloud's auto-scaling handles traffic spikes well. Just make sure you set up auto-scaling properly to handle those holiday rushes.

@part5.feedback.scenario3.public.description: Feedback for e-commerce with public cloud - good alternative

part5.feedback.default: That's an interesting choice. Think about the scenario's key requirements: security needs, cost constraints, and how usage might change over time.

@part5.feedback.default.description: Generic feedback for suboptimal solution choices
